title-group.article-title: When Are Modifications of Securitized Loans Beneficial to Investors?

abstract.p: Loan modification is widely discussed as an alternative to foreclosure, but little research has focused on quantifying its effect on loan performance. I quantify this effect early in the housing crisis by exploiting exogenous variation in the incentives to modify securitized nonagency loans. An additional modification reduces loan losses by 35.8% relative to the average loss; this reduction suggests that the marginal benefit of modification likely exceeded the marginal cost. Consistent with the idea that high-income borrowers may be better equipped to withstand bad economic times, I find that modifications are especially beneficial when borrowers have larger loans.

caption.p: Nonagency loan modifications by servicer type This figure shows the likelihood of modification for each month within six months of the loans becoming 60 + days delinquent. Loans are categorized by the type of servicer holding the servicing rights at the time the loan became delinquent. “Both-market servicers” includes servicers that manage loans both from mortgage-backed securities of government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs) and from nonagency mortgage-backed securities. “Non-agencyonly servicers” includes servicers that mostly manage nonagency loans. The step line shows the total number of mortgages in the United States that are delinquent 60 + days (foreclosure initiations are not included). The vertical line indicates the month during which Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac increased modification incentives in the GSE market. The gray area delimits when the modification rate becomes affected by the incentive fee. U. S.-level figures are calculated from the Mortgage Bankers Association’s National Delinquency Survey.
First stage: The effect of the incentive fee on modification rates

Total GSE loan modifications This figure shows the total number of modifications in the GSE market by quarter as reported by Inside Mortgage Finance. The vertical line indicates the quarter when the incentive fee in the GSE market was implemented.

GSE loan modifications of both-market servicers This figure shows the modification activity of both-market servicers in the GSE market by month. Data come from Fannie Mae’s and Freddie Mac’s Single-Family Loan Performance Datasets. The both-market servicers identified in the data sets are Bank of America, CitiMortgage, Countrywide, JP Morgan, Metlife, National City, PHH Mortgage, PNC, Suntrust, RFC-GMAC, WAMU, and Wells Fargo. Only loans that became 60 + days delinquent and that were serviced by the previous set of servicers are considered. Panel A shows likelihood of modification for each month within six months of the loans becoming 60 + days delinquent. The step line in panel A shows the total number of modifications within six months of delinquency, and the vertical line indicates the month during which Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac increased modification incentives in the GSE market and the gray area delimits when the modification rate becomes affected by the incentive fee. Panel B shows the total number of modifications performed by the twelve servicers by month. The vertical line indicates the month during which Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac increased modification incentives in the GSE market.
